Title: Randomised Controlled Trial of Score-Based Observation Versus Imaging in Early Equivocal Appendicitis

Background: This study aimed to evaluate whether early imaging leads to more diagnoses of acute appendicitis compared to initial observation and to assess the safety and feasibility of score-based observation in patients with equivocal appendicitis signs.

Methods: This single-centre randomised controlled trial was conducted at Helsinki University Hospital. Adults with suspected appendicitis, symptoms for less than 24 hours, and an Adult Appendicitis Score (AAS) of 11â€“15 were eligible. Participants were randomised 1:1 to imaging or observation groups using computer-based block randomisation. The primary outcome was the number of patients requiring treatment for acute appendicitis within 30 days. The analysis was intention-to-treat.

Results: From May 2016 to March 2020, 185 patients were randomised: 93 to imaging and 92 to observation. After exclusions, 93 and 88 patients were analysed, respectively. In the imaging group, 72% required treatment for appendicitis compared to 57% in the observation group (odds ratio 0.51, 95% CI 0.27 to 0.95; p = 0.032). No significant difference was found in complicated appendicitis (4% vs 2%) or negative appendicectomies (1% vs 1%). No adverse events were reported.

Interpretation: Score-based observation reduces the number of patients requiring treatment for appendicitis compared to early imaging. Trial registration: NCT02742402. Funding: Not specified.
